questions.question: A photographer needs to store 50GB of RAW image files that will be accessed frequently for the next month, then archived for long-term storage with occasional access. Which storage strategy would be most cost-effective?
options: Store on SSD initially, then move to HDD for archival
Store everything on optical discs from the start
Store on HDD throughout the entire process
questions.explanation: SSDs provide fast access for frequent use, but HDDs are more cost-effective for long-term storage of large files that are accessed occasionally. This hybrid approach balances performance and cost.

questions.question: Why do solid-state drives (SSDs) typically have better performance than traditional hard disk drives (HDDs) for random access operations?
options: SSDs have no moving mechanical parts
questions.explanation: SSDs use flash memory with no moving parts, allowing instant access to any location. HDDs must physically move read/write heads to different tracks, creating delays for random access patterns.

questions.question: A company needs to distribute software to customers on physical media that can be read by any computer but cannot be accidentally modified. Which storage medium would be most appropriate?
questions.explanation: DVD-R discs are read-only after burning, preventing accidental modification, have universal compatibility with optical drives, and are cost-effective for distribution purposes.

questions.question: What is the primary reason why magnetic storage devices are susceptible to data loss from strong magnetic fields, while optical and solid-state storage are not?
options: Magnetic devices store data using magnetic field orientations
Magnetic devices have lower storage density
questions.explanation: Magnetic storage encodes data as different magnetic field orientations on the medium. Strong external magnetic fields can alter these orientations, corrupting data. Optical and solid-state storage use different physical principles that are not affected by magnetism.

questions.question: A data center needs storage for a database that requires very low latency for frequent read/write operations, high reliability, and moderate capacity (2TB). Cost is not the primary concern. Which storage technology would be most suitable?
options: Optical storage with fast access time
questions.explanation: Enterprise SSDs provide the lowest latency due to no mechanical delays, highest reliability through advanced wear leveling and error correction, and can easily handle 2TB capacity requirements for mission-critical database operations.
